units.name: How do fields explain motion and electricity?

areasOfStudy.name: How do physicists explain motion in two dimensions?

topics.name: Newton's Laws of Motion
topics.subtitle: Forces in 1D and 2D
dotPoints: Investigate and apply theoretically and practically Newton's three laws of motion in situations where two or more coplanar forces act along a straight line and in two dimensions

topics.name: Uniform Circular Motion
topics.subtitle: Vehicles and strings
dotPoints: Investigate and analyse theoretically and practically the uniform circular motion of an object moving in a horizontal plane: F_net = mv²/r

topics.name: Satellite Motion
topics.subtitle: Natural and artificial satellites
dotPoints: Model natural and artificial satellite motion as uniform circular motion

topics.name: Vertical Circular Motion
topics.subtitle: Forces at top and bottom
dotPoints: Investigate and apply theoretically Newton's second law to circular motion in a vertical plane (forces at the highest and lowest positions only)

topics.name: Projectile Motion
topics.subtitle: Motion near Earth's surface
dotPoints: Investigate and analyse theoretically and practically the motion of projectiles near Earth's surface, including a qualitative description of the effects of air resistance

topics.name: Energy & Momentum Conservation
topics.subtitle: Isolated systems in 1D
dotPoints: Investigate and apply theoretically and practically the laws of energy and momentum conservation in isolated systems in one dimension

topics.name: Impulse
topics.subtitle: FΔt = mΔv
dotPoints: Investigate and analyse theoretically and practically impulse in an isolated system for collisions between objects moving in a straight line: FΔt = mΔv

topics.name: Work Done
topics.subtitle: Force × displacement
dotPoints: Investigate and apply theoretically and practically the concept of work done by a force

topics.name: Energy Transformations
topics.subtitle: KE, PE, elastic PE
dotPoints: Analyse transformations of energy between kinetic energy, elastic potential energy, gravitational potential energy and energy dissipated to the environment

areasOfStudy.name: How do things move without contact?

topics.name: Field Model Introduction
topics.subtitle: Describing fields
dotPoints: Describe gravitation, magnetism and electricity using a field model

topics.name: Comparing Field Types
topics.subtitle: Gravity, electricity, magnetism
dotPoints: Investigate and compare theoretically and practically gravitational, magnetic and electric fields, including directions and shapes of fields, attractive and repulsive effects, and the existence of dipoles and monopoles

topics.name: Gravitational & Electric Fields
topics.subtitle: Point masses and charges
dotPoints: Investigate and compare theoretically and practically gravitational fields and electrical fields about a point mass or charge (positive or negative) with reference to: the direction of the field, the shape of the field, the use of the inverse square law to determine the magnitude of the field, potential energy changes (qualitative) associated with a point mass or charge moving in the field

topics.name: Magnetic Field Shapes
topics.subtitle: Bar magnets, wires, loops, solenoids
dotPoints: Investigate and apply theoretically and practically a field model to magnetic phenomena, including shapes and directions of fields produced by bar magnets, and by current-carrying wires, loops and solenoids

topics.name: Field Classification
topics.subtitle: Static/changing, uniform/non-uniform
dotPoints: Identify fields as static or changing, and as uniform or non-uniform

topics.name: Electric Field Acceleration
topics.subtitle: Accelerating charges
dotPoints: Analyse the use of an electric field to accelerate a charge, including: electric field and electric force concepts, potential energy changes in a uniform electric field, the magnitude of the force on a charged particle

topics.name: Magnetic Force on Moving Charges
topics.subtitle: F = qvB
dotPoints: Analyse the use of a magnetic field to change the path of a charged particle, including: the magnitude and direction of the force applied to an electron beam by a magnetic field, the radius of the path followed by an electron in a magnetic field

topics.name: Gravitational Field Acceleration
topics.subtitle: Accelerating masses
dotPoints: Analyse the use of gravitational fields to accelerate mass, including: gravitational field and gravitational force concepts, potential energy changes in a uniform gravitational field

topics.name: PE from Graphs
topics.subtitle: Area under force-distance graphs
dotPoints: Analyse the change in gravitational potential energy from area under a force vs distance graph and area under a field vs distance graph multiplied by mass

topics.name: Satellites in Orbit
topics.subtitle: Gravity and normal force
dotPoints: Apply the concepts of force due to gravity and normal force including in relation to satellites in orbit where the orbits are assumed to be uniform and circular

topics.name: Orbital Motion
topics.subtitle: a = v²/r = 4π²r/T²
dotPoints: Model satellite motion (artificial, Moon, planet) as uniform circular orbital motion: a = v²/r = 4π²r/T²

topics.name: Field Interactions
topics.subtitle: Attract and repel
dotPoints: Describe the interaction of two fields, allowing that electric charges, magnetic poles and current carrying conductors can either attract or repel, whereas masses only attract each other

topics.name: Force on Current-Carrying Conductor
topics.subtitle: F = nIlB
dotPoints: Investigate and analyse theoretically and practically the force on a current carrying conductor due to an external magnetic field, F = nIlB

topics.name: DC Motors
topics.subtitle: Split ring commutator
dotPoints: Investigate and analyse theoretically and practically the operation of simple DC motors consisting of one coil, containing a number of loops of wire, which is free to rotate about an axis in a uniform magnetic field and including the use of a split ring commutator

topics.name: Motor Torque
topics.subtitle: Factors affecting torque
dotPoints: Investigate, qualitatively, the effect of current, external magnetic field and the number of loops of wire on the torque of a simple motor

topics.name: Particle Accelerators
topics.subtitle: Synchrotrons
dotPoints: Model the acceleration of particles in a particle accelerator (including synchrotrons) as uniform circular motion

areasOfStudy.name: How are fields used in electricity generation?

topics.name: Magnetic Flux
topics.subtitle: Φ = BA
dotPoints: Calculate magnetic flux when the magnetic field is perpendicular to the area, and describe the qualitative effect of differing angles between the area and the field

topics.name: Induced EMF
topics.subtitle: ε = −NΔΦ/Δt
dotPoints: Investigate and analyse theoretically and practically the generation of electromotive force (emf) including AC voltage and calculations using induced emf: ε = −NΔΦ_B/Δt

topics.name: Generators & Alternators
topics.subtitle: DC vs AC generation
dotPoints: Explain the production of DC voltage in DC generators and AC voltage in alternators, including the use of split ring commutators and slip rings respectively

topics.name: Photovoltaic Cells
topics.subtitle: Solar power and inverters
dotPoints: Describe the production of electricity using photovoltaic cells and the need for an inverter to convert power from DC to AC for use in the home

topics.name: AC Voltage Characteristics
topics.subtitle: Frequency, amplitude, Vp-p
dotPoints: Compare sinusoidal AC voltages produced as a result of the uniform rotation of a loop in a constant magnetic field

topics.name: RMS Voltage
topics.subtitle: Comparing AC and DC
dotPoints: Compare alternating voltage expressed as the root-mean-square (rms) to a constant DC voltage developing the same power in a resistive component

topics.name: Transformers
topics.subtitle: N₁/N₂ = V₁/V₂ = I₂/I₁
dotPoints: Analyse transformer action with reference to electromagnetic induction for an ideal transformer

topics.name: Transmission Losses
topics.subtitle: Power loss in transmission lines
dotPoints: Analyse the supply of power by considering transmission losses across transmission lines

units.name: How have creative ideas and investigation revolutionised thinking in physics?

areasOfStudy.name: How has understanding about the physical world changed?

topics.name: Light as an EM Wave
topics.subtitle: Transverse electromagnetic waves
dotPoints: Describe light as a transverse electromagnetic wave which is produced by the acceleration of charges, which in turn produces changing electric fields and associated changing magnetic fields

topics.name: Speed of Light
topics.subtitle: c in a vacuum
dotPoints: Identify that all electromagnetic waves travel at the same speed, c, in a vacuum

topics.name: Standing Waves
topics.subtitle: Superposition and reflection
dotPoints: Explain the formation of a standing wave resulting from the superposition of a travelling wave and its reflection
Analyse the formation of standing waves (only those with nodes at both ends is required)

topics.name: Diffraction
topics.subtitle: λ/w ratio and imaging limits
dotPoints: Investigate and explain theoretically and practically diffraction as the directional spread of various frequencies with reference to different gap width or obstacle size, including the qualitative effect of changing the λ/w ratio, and apply this to limitations of imaging using electromagnetic waves

topics.name: Young's Double Slit
topics.subtitle: Interference and path difference
dotPoints: Explain the results of Young's double slit experiment with reference to: evidence for the wave-like nature of light, constructive and destructive interference of coherent waves in terms of path differences, effect of wavelength, distance of screen and slit separation on interference patterns

topics.name: Photon Energy
topics.subtitle: E = hf = hc/λ
dotPoints: Apply the quantised energy of photons: E = hf = hc/λ

topics.name: Photoelectric Effect
topics.subtitle: Ek max = hf − φ
dotPoints: Analyse the photoelectric effect with reference to: evidence for the particle-like nature of light, experimental characteristics, Einstein's explanation

topics.name: Wave Model Limitations
topics.subtitle: What waves can't explain
dotPoints: Describe the limitations of the wave model of light in explaining the photoelectric effect

topics.name: Electron Diffraction
topics.subtitle: Evidence for matter waves
dotPoints: Interpret electron diffraction patterns as evidence for the wave-like nature of matter
Distinguish between the diffraction patterns produced by photons and electrons

topics.name: de Broglie Wavelength
topics.subtitle: λ = h/p
dotPoints: Calculate the de Broglie wavelength of matter: λ = h/p
Compare the momentum of photons and of matter of the same wavelength including calculations using: p = h/λ

topics.name: Wave-Particle Duality
topics.subtitle: Double slit for photons and electrons
dotPoints: Interpret the single photon and the electron double slit experiment as evidence for the dual nature of light and matter

topics.name: Atomic Spectra
topics.subtitle: Absorption and emission
dotPoints: Explain the production of atomic absorption and emission line spectra, including those from the hydrogen atom as evidence for quantisation of energy states of electrons in atoms

topics.name: Special Relativity Postulates
topics.subtitle: Einstein's two postulates
dotPoints: Describe Einstein's two postulates of special relativity
Compare Einstein's and Newton's explanations of time and length

topics.name: Time Dilation
topics.subtitle: t = γt₀
dotPoints: Explain time dilation using thought experiments involving light clocks
Apply time dilation formula: t = t₀γ = t₀/√(1 − v²/c²)

topics.name: Length Contraction
topics.subtitle: L = L₀/γ
dotPoints: Explain length contraction using a light clock travelling parallel to its direction of motion
Apply length contraction formula: L = L₀/γ = L₀√(1 − v²/c²)

topics.name: Relativity Applications
topics.subtitle: Muons, GPS, accelerators
dotPoints: Describe applications of special relativity including muon decay, GPS, and particle accelerators

topics.name: Mass-Energy Equivalence
topics.subtitle: E = mc², E = γmc²
dotPoints: Apply mass-energy equivalence: Etot = γmc², E₀ = mc², Ek = (γ − 1)mc²

topics.name: Mass-Energy Applications
topics.subtitle: Sun, annihilation, accelerators
dotPoints: Describe applications of mass-energy equivalence: the Sun, annihilation, particle accelerators
